questions.text: What is the most spoken language in the world by total number of speakers (native + non-native)?
questions.explanation: English has the most total speakers worldwide (over 1.4 billion) when combining native and non-native speakers.

questions.text: What is the most spoken language in the world by number of NATIVE speakers?
questions.explanation: Mandarin Chinese has the most native speakers, with over 900 million people speaking it as their first language.

questions.text: The English word 'salary' comes from the Latin word 'salarium,' which is related to what substance?
questions.explanation: Salarium relates to 'sal' (salt). Roman soldiers were sometimes paid in salt or given an allowance to buy it.

questions.text: Which alphabet has the most letters?
questions.explanation: The Khmer alphabet has 74 letters, making it the largest alphabet in the world according to the Guinness Book of World Records.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'ubiquitous' mean?
questions.explanation: Ubiquitous means present, appearing, or found everywhere. It comes from the Latin 'ubique' meaning 'everywhere.'

questions.text: What is the longest word in the English language that uses no repeated letters?
questions.explanation: Subdermatoglyphic (17 letters) is the longest common English word with no repeating letters. It refers to the patterns beneath the skin on fingertips.

questions.text: The French phrase 'c'est la vie' translates to what in English?
questions.explanation: C'est la vie literally translates to 'that's life' or 'such is life,' expressing acceptance of how things are.

questions.text: Which of these languages is NOT part of the Romance language family?
questions.explanation: Dutch is a Germanic language. Romance languages (Portuguese, Romanian, Italian, Spanish, French) all descended from Latin.

questions.text: What does the idiom 'to burn the midnight oil' mean?
questions.explanation: This idiom means to work late into the night, originating from the days when oil lamps were used for light.

questions.text: Which writing system reads from right to left?
questions.explanation: Arabic is written and read from right to left. Hebrew and Urdu also follow this direction.

questions.text: The word 'tsunami' comes from which language?
questions.explanation: Tsunami comes from Japanese: 'tsu' (harbor) + 'nami' (wave), literally meaning 'harbor wave.'

questions.text: What is a 'palindrome'?

options.A: A word borrowed from another language
options.B: A word that reads the same forwards and backwards
options.C: A word with two opposite meanings
options.D: A word that sounds like what it describes

questions.explanation: A palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards, like 'racecar,' 'level,' or 'madam.'

questions.text: How many official languages does the United Nations have?
questions.explanation: The UN has 6 official languages: Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian, and Spanish.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'ephemeral' mean?
questions.explanation: Ephemeral means lasting for a very short time. It comes from the Greek 'ephemeros' meaning 'lasting only a day.'

questions.text: Which language has the concept of 'click consonants' as a fundamental part of its phonology?
questions.explanation: Xhosa, a Bantu language spoken in South Africa, extensively uses click consonants as regular speech sounds.

questions.text: The German word 'Schadenfreude' describes what feeling?
questions.explanation: Schadenfreude combines 'Schaden' (damage) and 'Freude' (joy) â€” pleasure derived from another person's misfortune.

questions.text: Which of these is an example of an 'onomatopoeia'?
questions.explanation: Onomatopoeia is a word that imitates the sound it describes. 'Buzz' sounds like the noise a bee makes.

questions.text: Korean writing (Hangul) was invented by which historical figure?
questions.explanation: King Sejong the Great of the Joseon Dynasty created Hangul in 1443 to promote literacy among common people.

questions.text: What does the Latin phrase 'carpe diem' mean?

options.B: In the year of our Lord

questions.explanation: Carpe diem means 'seize the day.' It was coined by the Roman poet Horace, urging people to make the most of the present.

questions.text: What is the study of the origin and history of words called?
questions.explanation: Etymology is the study of word origins and how their meanings have changed over time.

questions.text: Which country has the most official languages?
questions.explanation: Zimbabwe has 16 official languages, including Shona, Ndebele, English, and 13 others recognized in its 2013 constitution.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'pragmatic' mean?
questions.explanation: Pragmatic means dealing with things sensibly and realistically, focused on practical results rather than theory.

questions.text: The word 'robot' was first used in which language?
questions.explanation: The word 'robot' was introduced by Czech writer Karel Capek in his 1920 play R.U.R., from the Czech 'robota' meaning forced labor.

questions.text: What type of writing system does Japanese use that combines multiple scripts?
questions.explanation: Japanese uses three writing systems together: hiragana (native words), katakana (foreign words), and kanji (Chinese characters).

questions.text: The idiom 'it's raining cats and dogs' means what?

options.A: Animals are falling from the sky
options.B: A pet store is having a sale

questions.explanation: This English idiom simply means it is raining very heavily or there is a downpour.

questions.text: Which of these languages is a 'tonal language' where pitch changes the meaning of a word?
questions.explanation: Mandarin Chinese uses four tones (plus a neutral tone). The syllable 'ma' can mean mother, hemp, horse, or scold depending on tone.

questions.text: What is the origin of the word 'quarantine'?
questions.explanation: Quarantine comes from the Italian 'quarantina' meaning 'forty days,' the period ships had to wait before passengers could go ashore during plague outbreaks.

questions.text: American Sign Language (ASL) is most closely related to which other sign language?
questions.explanation: ASL descended from French Sign Language (LSF), brought to America by Laurent Clerc in the early 1800s. ASL and BSL are actually quite different.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'cacophony' mean?
questions.explanation: Cacophony means a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds. It comes from Greek 'kakos' (bad) + 'phone' (sound).

questions.text: What is the only letter that does not appear in any U.S. state name?
questions.explanation: The letter Q does not appear in the name of any of the 50 U.S. states.

questions.text: The Spanish phrase 'mi casa es su casa' translates to what?
questions.explanation: Mi casa es su casa literally means 'my house is your house,' expressing hospitality and welcome.

questions.text: What is a 'portmanteau' in linguistics?

options.B: A blend of two words into one
options.C: A word from a dead language

questions.explanation: A portmanteau blends two words together, like 'brunch' (breakfast + lunch) or 'smog' (smoke + fog).

questions.text: Which ancient writing system used wedge-shaped marks pressed into clay tablets?
questions.explanation: Cuneiform, developed in ancient Sumer (modern Iraq), used a reed stylus to press wedge-shaped marks into wet clay tablets.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'sycophant' mean?

options.A: A person who flatters to gain advantage
options.D: A person who predicts the future

questions.explanation: A sycophant is a person who acts obsequiously toward someone important to gain an advantage; a flatterer or toady.

questions.text: The word 'alphabet' comes from the first two letters of which writing system?
questions.explanation: The word 'alphabet' derives from the Greek letters Alpha and Beta, the first two letters of the Greek alphabet.

questions.text: In which language does the word 'wiki' (as in Wikipedia) originate?
questions.explanation: Wiki comes from the Hawaiian word 'wiki' meaning 'quick.' Wikipedia founder Ward Cunningham named the first wiki software after it.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used letter in the English language?
questions.explanation: The letter E is the most frequently used letter in English, appearing in about 11% of all words.

questions.text: The Japanese concept 'wabi-sabi' relates to what?
questions.explanation: Wabi-sabi is a Japanese aesthetic concept centered on finding beauty in imperfection and accepting the transience of things.

questions.text: What does the idiom 'break a leg' mean in theater?
questions.explanation: In theater, 'break a leg' is a way of wishing someone good luck, since saying 'good luck' directly is considered bad luck.

questions.text: Esperanto, the most widely spoken constructed language, was created by a speaker of which language?
questions.explanation: L.L. Zamenhof, who created Esperanto in 1887, was a Polish ophthalmologist who grew up in Bialystok, Poland (then part of the Russian Empire).

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'ambiguous' mean?

options.B: Open to more than one interpretation

questions.explanation: Ambiguous means open to more than one interpretation or having a double meaning; unclear or inexact.

questions.text: Which of these is an 'agglutinative' language, where words are formed by stringing together morphemes?
questions.explanation: Turkish is agglutinative, building complex words by adding suffixes. For example, 'evlerinizden' means 'from your houses' built from ev+ler+iniz+den.

questions.text: The English word 'ketchup' likely originates from which language?
questions.explanation: Ketchup likely derives from the Hokkien Chinese word 'ke-tsiap,' a fermented fish sauce, which was adapted through Malay and then English.

questions.text: What is the term for a word that has the opposite meaning of another word?
questions.explanation: An antonym is a word with the opposite meaning of another word, such as 'hot' and 'cold' or 'big' and 'small.'

questions.text: Which language family does Finnish belong to?
questions.explanation: Finnish belongs to the Uralic language family, along with Hungarian and Estonian. It is not related to its Scandinavian neighbors.

questions.text: The Rosetta Stone helped scholars decipher which writing system?
questions.explanation: The Rosetta Stone, with its text in hieroglyphics, Demotic, and Greek, enabled Jean-Francois Champollion to decipher Egyptian hieroglyphics in 1822.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'loquacious' mean?
questions.explanation: Loquacious means very talkative, from the Latin 'loqui' meaning 'to speak.'

questions.text: What is the shortest complete sentence in English?
questions.explanation: Go. is the shortest grammatically complete sentence in English, containing a subject (implied 'you') and a verb.

questions.text: The Italian phrase 'dolce far niente' means what?
questions.explanation: Dolce far niente translates to 'the sweetness of doing nothing,' describing the pleasure of idleness and relaxation.

questions.text: How many characters does a literate Chinese adult typically know?
questions.explanation: A literate Chinese adult typically knows 6,000 to 8,000 characters, though only about 3,000-4,000 are needed for everyday reading.

questions.text: What is the term for a word that sounds like another but has a different meaning and spelling?
questions.explanation: A homophone is a word that sounds the same as another but has a different meaning and often different spelling, like 'there,' 'their,' and 'they're.'

questions.text: The word 'avocado' comes from the Nahuatl (Aztec) word 'ahuacatl,' which originally meant what?
questions.explanation: The Nahuatl word 'ahuacatl' meant 'testicle,' likely referring to the shape of the fruit. Spanish colonizers adapted the word to 'avocado.'

questions.text: Which of these is a 'dead language' that is no longer spoken as a native tongue but is still studied?
questions.explanation: Latin is a dead language with no native speakers, though it remains widely studied and used in science, law, and the Catholic Church.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'juxtapose' mean?

options.B: To place side by side for comparison

questions.explanation: Juxtapose means to place close together or side by side, especially for comparison or contrast.

questions.text: The Hawaiian language has how many letters in its alphabet?
questions.explanation: The Hawaiian alphabet has 13 letters: 5 vowels (a, e, i, o, u) and 8 consonants (h, k, l, m, n, p, w, and the okina or glottal stop).

questions.text: What is the term for a new word that enters a language?
questions.explanation: A neologism is a newly coined word or expression. Examples include 'selfie,' 'blog,' and 'emoji.'

questions.text: The word 'emoji' comes from which language?
questions.explanation: Emoji comes from Japanese: 'e' (picture) + 'moji' (character). Its resemblance to 'emotion' in English is a coincidence.

questions.text: What does the German word 'Wanderlust' mean?
questions.explanation: Wanderlust combines 'wandern' (to hike/wander) and 'Lust' (desire), meaning a strong longing or impulse to travel.

questions.text: Which punctuation mark is called an 'interrobang'?
questions.explanation: The interrobang combines a question mark and exclamation point (?! or the single character). It was invented in 1962 by Martin K. Speckter.

questions.text: Braille is a writing system that represents letters using what?
questions.explanation: Braille uses patterns of raised dots arranged in cells of up to six dots, allowing visually impaired people to read by touch.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'equivocate' mean?

options.B: To use ambiguous language to mislead

questions.explanation: To equivocate means to use vague or ambiguous language to avoid committing to a position or to deceive.

questions.text: The English word 'kindergarten' was borrowed from which language?
questions.explanation: Kindergarten is German for 'children's garden.' It was coined by Friedrich Frobel in 1840 for his early childhood education program.

questions.text: What is an 'oxymoron'?

options.A: A figure of speech combining contradictory terms

questions.explanation: An oxymoron combines contradictory words for effect, like 'jumbo shrimp,' 'deafening silence,' or 'bittersweet.'

questions.text: Which of these scripts is written vertically from top to bottom?
questions.explanation: Traditional Mongolian script is written vertically, running from top to bottom in columns that go from left to right.

questions.text: The phrase 'hakuna matata' from The Lion King comes from which language?
questions.explanation: Hakuna matata is a Swahili phrase meaning 'no worries' or 'no problems.' Swahili is widely spoken in East Africa.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'benevolent' mean?
questions.explanation: Benevolent means well-meaning and kindly, from the Latin 'bene' (well) + 'volent' (wishing).

questions.text: What is a 'lingua franca'?

options.B: A language used for communication between groups with different native tongues

questions.explanation: A lingua franca is a bridge language used between speakers of different native languages. English serves as the global lingua franca today.

questions.text: The English word 'chocolate' traces back to which indigenous American language?
questions.explanation: Chocolate comes from the Nahuatl (Aztec) word 'xocolatl,' likely meaning 'bitter water,' via Spanish.

questions.text: Which of these sentences uses the Oxford comma?

options.A: I like cats, dogs and birds.
options.B: I like cats, dogs, and birds.
options.C: I like cats and dogs and birds.

questions.explanation: The Oxford (or serial) comma is the comma placed before the conjunction in a list of three or more items: 'cats, dogs, and birds.'

questions.text: What is the most translated book in the world?
questions.explanation: The Bible is the most translated book in the world, with full translations into over 700 languages and partial translations into thousands more.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'didactic' mean?
questions.explanation: Didactic means intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive. From Greek 'didaktikos' (apt at teaching).

questions.text: The idiom 'the ball is in your court' means what?

options.B: It's your turn to take action

questions.explanation: This idiom, borrowed from tennis, means it's now your responsibility or turn to take action or make a decision.

questions.text: Which of these languages is an 'isolate,' meaning it has no known relatives?
questions.explanation: Basque, spoken in the Basque Country spanning Spain and France, is a language isolate with no proven genetic relationship to any other language.

questions.text: What is the word for a letter or symbol that represents a whole word or phrase?
questions.explanation: A logogram (or logograph) is a character representing a word or phrase, such as Chinese characters, '&' for 'and,' or '$' for 'dollar.'

questions.text: The Portuguese word 'saudade' describes what untranslatable feeling?

options.B: A deep emotional longing for something absent

questions.explanation: Saudade describes a deep, melancholic longing for something or someone that is absent, often considered untranslatable into English.

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'verbose' mean?
questions.explanation: Verbose means using or expressed in more words than are needed; wordy. From Latin 'verbosus' (full of words).

questions.text: Which of these ancient scripts remains undeciphered?
questions.explanation: Linear A, used by the Minoan civilization on Crete, remains undeciphered. Linear B (Mycenaean Greek) was deciphered by Michael Ventris in 1952.

questions.text: The English word 'shampoo' comes from which language?
questions.explanation: Shampoo comes from the Hindi/Urdu word 'champo,' an imperative form meaning 'to press or massage,' related to head massage.

questions.text: What is a 'cognate' in linguistics?

options.A: A word that sounds like its meaning
options.B: A word in different languages that shares a common origin
options.C: A word with no plural form
options.D: A word invented by a single person

questions.explanation: Cognates are words in different languages that have a common etymological origin, like English 'night,' German 'Nacht,' and Latin 'nox.'

questions.text: What does the SAT-level word 'quintessential' mean?

options.B: Representing the most perfect example of something

questions.explanation: Quintessential means representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class. It originally referred to the 'fifth essence' in ancient philosophy.
